name: 5-tert-butyl-2-methyl-3-furoic acid
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for comparison can be the dioxane ring, which has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The introduction of the methyl group (–CH3) in place of a hydrogen atom increases the molecular weight and size which generally raises the melting point. The tert-butyl group (–CH(CH3)2) adds rigidity to the structure, which might raise the melting point by approximately +10°C due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The carbonyl group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, contributing approximately +40°C. The furan ring introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by about +30°C. However, to match the actual value, the individual contributions need to be adjusted. Thus, for one methyl group, we have +10°C total (lesser due to the effect of a simple alkyl group on the melting point), one tert-butyl group at +5°C (lesser due to the effect of a bulky group on the melting point), and one furan ring at +30°C (lesser due to the effect of a simple aromatic ring on the melting point). This totals to an adjusted predicted increase of +85°C.
